learning_outcomes.description: Learn about drinking water quality, supplies, and health in urban and remote environments
Evaluate a risk based approach to drinking water treatment and production
Evaluate drinking water treatment processes, including design and analysis of processes
Understand the principles of advanced water treatment in the face of water scarcity

assessments.task_description:
Problem portfolios are formal assessment exercises requiring detailed analysis and thoughtful responses. You will submit these two times during the course as part of your evaluation.

  • Problem Portfolio 1 covers Modules 1 to 5, submissions open from 28/07/25 until 5/09/25 at 4 PM
  • Problem Portfolio 2 covers Modules 6 to 10, submissions open from 1/09/25 until 17/10/25 at 4 PM

Portfolios must be typed using word processing software, converted to PDF format, and submitted electronically. You can submit anytime during the submission period indicated above. We recommend completing the exercises as you progress through each learning module.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

Course content is delivered through the following modules:

  1. Water quality
  2. Risk based approach to water supply
  3. Water sources
  4. Conventional technologies: coagulation, flocculation, and aquatic chemistry
  5. Conventional technologies: design of sedimentation systems
  6. Conventional technologies: media filtration systems
  7. Conventional technologies: disinfection, chemical and UV
  8. Advanced technologies: membrane based water production
  9. Advanced technologies: chemical and biochemical treatment, advance oxidation, ion exchange, ozone, and biological activated carbon
  10. Supply planning: Water customers, community consultation and indigenous communities and water.
  11. Challenges in remote and low-cost drinking water supply
  12. Water industry experience

Digital material will be provided on Blackboard

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
